Review Nanostructure in energy conversion Saskia Buller a Jennifer Strunk a b * a Max-Planck-Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion, Mülheim Ruhr, Germany Max-Planck-Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion Mülheim Ruhr Germany b Center for Nanointegration Duisburg-Essen, University of Duisburg-Essen, Germany Center for Nanointegration Duisburg-Essen University of Duisburg-Essen Germany * Corresponding author at: Max-Planck-Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion, Mülheim/Ruhr, Germany. Max-Planck-Institute for Chemical Energy Conversion, Mülheim/Ruhr, Germany Nanostructured and nanosized materials are widely applied to tackle the pressing challenges associated with energy conversion. In this conceptual review, rather than highlighting separate examples, we aim to give a general overview about where and how nanostructure design can be beneficial in the three major research fields (photo)thermal chemical energy conversion, electrochemical energy conversion, and solar energy conversion. It will be shown that in many cases the design of catalytically active nanostructures is the main task and that especially for catalysts nanostructure and activity are inseparably linked to each other. Moreover, electrochemical and photochemical processes are complicated by the overlap of multiple processes that all need to be optimized, including in particular light absorption, charge migration, recombination and trapping events and surface processes. It will also be shown how the development of materials for new challenges can often be based on our knowledge on existing materials for related applications. Graphical abstract Potential applications and challenges associated with the use of nanostructured materials in (photo)thermal, electrochemical and solar energy conversion are discussed in this conceptual review. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Renewable energy Nanostructure Electrochemical energy Solar power 1 Introduction It becomes more and more recognized in wide parts of the world that the current system of energy conversion and storage will not be able to last forever. In particular, the main foundation of today's energy infrastructure is based on fossil fuels, namely crude oil, natural gas, and coal. Although the predicted time scales of depletion of the one or other resource might differ as a function of the employed model [1–5], e.g. considering “physical” vs. “economic exhaustion” [1], it is undoubted that alternative solutions will be needed at some point, and potentially sooner rather than later [3–5]. Since uranium is not a renewable resource, either, and since nuclear power has become rather unpopular, in particular due to health and safety issues, nuclear power will likely not be a viable option for the long term [5–9]. Available renewable resources from geothermal energy, hydroelectric or wind power will likely not be sufficient to fulfill the world-wide energy demand; even if their combined full potential is exploited [10]. The only sufficiently available resource we can certainly rely on for the upcoming millions of years is the sun. The energy of the sun reaching the earth's surface is certainly much greater than the recent average annual world-wide consumption, and the factors reported for the excess of the irradiation energy of the sun are ranging between almost six thousand [11] to about four order of magnitude [12,13]. Or, in other words, if we were able to convert and store all solar energy reaching the surface of the earth in one hour, we would meet the world-wide energy demand of a whole year [4,5]. However, for this purpose we still need to develop efficient tools and processes that allow harvesting and storage of solar energy in a practical form [4,5]. Many approaches are currently in development that are partially linked to each other, but partially go entirely separate ways. Energy conversion could take place, for example, from photons to current (photovoltaics), from photons to chemicals (biotechnological processes or photocatalysis), from photons to heat and/or chemicals (solar thermal approaches), from heat to electricity (thermoelectrics), from electricity to chemicals (electrolyzers) and in certainly many more ways. Energy might then be stored, for example, in forms as different as potential energy in water reservoirs at high elevation, electrical energy in batteries, or chemical energy in chemicals bonds of molecules with high energy density [5]. There are scientific approaches in all of those directions, and this is also strongly advised, (a) because we do not know yet which scientific breakthroughs are still achievable in any of those fields and (b) because at present we rely on a mix of energy conversion technologies, too, which demonstrates that different technologies might be needed in different areas of the world and different segments of industry and production. At the same time, in recent years, there has been much effort to reach further and further into the “nano” domain and to ever smaller sizes, down to the isolated atoms. It is the aim to manipulate materials on their most elementary scale, that is, in their general atomic composition and the arrangement of their smallest building blocks [14,15]. Furthermore, sizes and shapes of certain crucial building blocks are made smaller and smaller, because properties might be achieved otherwise not observed in the parent bulk material. Manipulating materials on the nanoscale also requires tools and methods that allow monitoring the achieved manipulation on the nanoscale, if possible under conditions as close as possible to those in the targeted field of application. The high importance of such studies of the working systems, “in situ” and “in operando”, originates from the realization that a structure once established in a particular biological, physical or chemical synthesis not necessarily persists under reaction conditions [16,17]. Often, not just one material is modified and manipulated on the nanoscale. Sometimes, the peculiar properties are a consequence of interfaces and contacts established between different (nano) materials. Those materials, often referred to as “hybrid nanostructures” [18–20], might not only display the properties of their separate components, but also new features not observed in the separate building blocks. As can be seen from the introduction above, both the terms “nanostructure” and “energy conversion” are much discussed topics nowadays. At first glance, though, they appear entirely unrelated to each other. To the general public, the undoubtedly “macro-sized” solar panels, wind parks, power plants, or catalytic reactors, do not appear to have anything to do with “nano” at all. Yet, it is often the smallest units of a material that make all the difference. Regardless whether the aim is the development of more efficient solar panels, more active catalysts, or longer lasting coatings or electrodes, it has been recognized that modern tools for material modification and manipulation on the nanoscale might help in finding the solution [21]. For example, in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, the possibly most prominent example for the importance of nanosize or nanostructure is catalysis by the noble metal gold: It is well known that bulk gold is chemically absolutely inert; this is a property that has been exploited in the history of humankind to create artifacts that lasted for centuries. On the other hand, reducing the size of gold to that of clusters of a few nanometers and depositing those nanoparticles on oxide supports leads to the formation of a material with high catalytic activity, for example in selective and total oxidation reactions [22–28]. In the field of photocatalysis, the natural oxygen evolution site is the best example for the high importance of nanostructure: Only the one specific Mn4O5Ca cluster with its evolutionary developed protein matrix is active for the oxygen evolution, and so far attempts to replicate such a system (bio)chemically have failed [29,30]. Since the research fields of nanostructured materials and energy conversion are wide enough that books have been written about them (see for example, refs. [31–37]), we have to set certain limits for the scope of this review. With respect to “nanostructure”, we will focus on inorganic materials. Undoubtedly, biological and organic materials have an important role in the world-wide energy system, in particular natural photosynthesis. However, in biology and to certain extend in organic chemistry the nanostructure appears to be rather inseparably linked to the chemical composition, i.e. the type of protein or amino acid attached to a certain site or chain. In inorganic materials, on the other hand, shape, size and composition can often be varied in a wide range more or less independent of each other. Furthermore, we will address energy conversion only in the sense of “renewable energy”, thus excluding fossil fuels and nuclear power. Renewable energy conversion, however, cannot be addressed without at the same time discussing the issue of energy storage, too, the latter often being the more pressing problem [38]. In this review, energy storage will only be addressed with respect to chemical bonds in molecules with high energy density, i.e. by means of the synthesis of so-called “solar fuels”. It appears most reasonable to split the diverse topic of energy conversion into the following sub-topics: • (Photo)thermal chemical energy conversion • Electrochemical energy conversion • (Direct) solar energy conversion There is certainly significant overlap between all three subtopics. As an example, one might consider a hypothetical photoelectrochemical cell operating at elevated temperatures and under solar light irradiation, in which CO2 is converted to methanol. This device would clearly fall into all three categories. Consequently, the following introduction to the three topics will set the boundaries and clarify the definitions that we have adopted in this review. In the field of (photo)thermal chemical energy conversion, emphasis is clearly put on the production of substances that can be, or at least bear the potential to be, used as fuels on the large scale. Furthermore, in this part of the review, we will only highlight processes that can already be operated on the industrial scale or appear to reach this stage in the near future. Typical processes in this category are the synthesis of methanol or long-chain hydrocarbons from carbon dioxide or the production of liquid fuels from biomass. Consequently, this part of the review will focus for a large part on the properties and the development of (heterogeneous) catalysts, since most of the processes mentioned above require a certain catalyst with well-defined properties. In the field of (photo)thermal chemical energy conversion we will show that the challenges in this regard are often associated with the changing raw material supply, and the drive towards a use of carbon dioxide as feedstock instead of fossil-derived synthesis gas. It will become clear that a thorough understanding of today's large scale catalytic processes is the best basis to employ nanostructuring technology successfully and fruitfully to develop improved catalyst systems for new challenges. In the part of electrochemical energy conversion we will highlight the development of suitable, stable and cost-efficient electrode materials and electrocatalysts. Since electrochemical cells combined with photovoltaics currently appear to be a suitable solution for larger scale solar fuel production, i.e. for the splitting of water to generate hydrogen, the development of active and stable catalysts and electrode materials without the use of noble metals is of prime importance. The latter would have little potential for large scale application to satisfy world-wide energy demand. The development of those materials should ideally be based on a thorough understanding of the underlying processes, so the necessary (elementary) reactions associated with the electrocatalytic splitting of water will also be discussed in this section of the review. A combination of manganese oxides as catalysts and carbon materials as electrodes appears to be a promising solution, because those materials are all cheap and abundant. Moreover, a wide variety of nanostructuring approaches to increase the performance are available for these materials, which will be particularly highlighted. The two most important devices to be considered in the field of solar energy conversion are photovoltaics and photocatalysts. In this field, the main definition is based on the direct use of (sun) light to initiate a reaction, that is, either the generation of a current (photovoltaics) or the synthesis of chemicals (photocatalysis or photoelectochemistry). In this part of the review, we will highlight the influence of size and structure of a material on properties such as light absorption, charge carrier mobility or the lifetime of photogenerated charge carriers, as those unifying concepts are needed in both the development of materials for photovoltaics and for photocatalysis. In the field of solar energy conversion, it will be shown that many concepts for efficient absorption and conversion of solar energy are already known. While those approaches have often already found their way into application in photovoltaics, the use for photocatalysis is often still being explored. In spite of all the research efforts, the complex interplay between light absorption properties, charge transfer processes and catalytic functionalities is not yet understood for many materials. Consequently, rather than discussing particular examples, we highlight the potential of nanostructuring to specifically modify either of the functionalities mentioned above (light absorption, charge transfer, catalysis). The different aspects of energy conversion and storage thus discussed in the present review are put into perspective in Fig. 1 . It needs to be noted that this figure is not a complete picture of all possible ways. It considers energy conversion only between the three cornerstones of (1) solar energy supply, (2) the need to recycle CO2 in energy conversion (as opposed to emitting it when fossil fuels are used), and (3) the end user/customer in continuous need of energy, which requires storage options. Fossil fuels as raw materials are not considered here, and with respect to solar fuels, only liquid products are considered, although, for example, methane or ammonia might be possible alternatives. For a more complete overview over such processes, please refer to Ref. [39]. Many excellent reviews on related topics already exist, for example on the classification and application of nanostructured materials in general [40], nanostructures and nanomaterials in photovoltaics [41–45], for example in quantum-dot solar cells [46,47] or in photoelectrodes for dye-sensitized solar cells [48–50], nanostructure architectures for solar energy conversion [10], nanostructures for (solar) water splitting [51–54], including artificial photosynthesis approaches [55], nanostructures, nanomaterials and nano-objects in heterogeneous catalysis [14–16,56–59], or for catalysis and energy storage [60,61], 1D-materials and hetero-nanostructures for photocatalysis [62,63], nanostructures for plasmon-enhanced applications [64–68], nanostructures and nanosize materials for electrode and catalyst materials in energy storage [69–78], for the use in fuels cells [79] or electrocatalysis [80], or on carbon nanotubes for energy applications [81]. This leads to the question which new aspects and views can still be contributed to this field. So, rather than giving a complete overview over all possible examples in just one research field, the central focus of our critical review is put on the discussion of the general concepts associated with nanostructure and nanosize that are currently explored – or could possibly be explored in the future – to provide enhanced means of energy conversion and storage. 2 Nanostructure in (photo)thermal chemical energy conversion 2.1 Introduction: catalysis and nanostructure In this part of the review we will highlight the design of nanostructured materials for the implementation and modification of already established large-scale industrial processes as solution for new challenges. In this respect, new approaches in synthesis gas chemistry are discussed, in particular the synthesis of methanol or hydrocarbons from CO2 instead of a CO-rich synthesis gas. We will also briefly look at solar thermal approaches, and the generation of liquid fuels from biomass, to judge whether nanostructured materials can be of use in those fields. In general, all these processes fit right into the debate and challenge of a changing raw material supply for industry [15]. However, in this review, only the supply with (liquid) fuels and the storage of energy will be discussed. Engineering of nanostructures can serve as basis to develop suitable solutions whenever the main challenge can be identified as the development of a new suitable (heterogeneous) catalyst, or the targeted modification on an existing catalyst to fit a new purpose [15]. The engineering of the nanostructure can then built upon the knowledge of the classical heterogeneous catalyst, for example the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst that makes methanol from CO-rich synthesis gas [82]. Furthermore, making catalytic processes more sustainable can also be achieved by lowering the number of reaction steps and increasing the overall selectivity, and nanostructure engineering can help to reach those goals [15]. Certainly, alternative processes for the production of liquid fuels, for example (bio)ethanol, can also be realized applying biotechnological approaches. While it appears undoubted that nanostructure is of high importance in biocatalysis, too, for example in the targeted engineering of enzymes [83], this research field is outside the scope of this review. In general, catalytic properties of solids cannot be discussed at all without looking at their nanostructure, in particular on their surfaces. While the geometric and electronic structure of the bulk is not irrelevant for the catalytic reaction, it is mostly the structure of the surface that controls catalytic activity [14,16]. First and foremost, one needs to be aware that any surface of a solid is always a defect as such, because the otherwise stable, infinite bulk structure is disturbed. The termination of the bulk structure in (at least) one direction necessarily implies the presence of under coordinated atoms that seek to stabilize themselves. This is particular an issue for those surfaces that are unstable due to a dipole moment normal to them in the bulk structure (Tasker's rule) [84]. Surfaces can stabilize themselves for example by surface reconstruction, formation of cation/anion vacancies or the adsorption of molecules from their surroundings [85,86]. So, it is not unlikely to expect a surface termination that has little to do with the bulk of the material. In nanosized materials, moreover, the surface-to-volume ratio is very high, thus implying a high amount of disorder, defects and strain [15]. In many reactions it also needs to be considered that the activity of all possible exposed crystal facets might differ [14]. Active sites with a particular structure need to be exposed that are often very complex in nature. Often, the catalytic reaction needs strained and defective sites. Such sites could be anion or cation vacancies, for example oxygen vacancies in methanol synthesis from CO on ZnO [87,88], step edges, for example for the splitting of nitrogen in ammonia synthesis over Ru [89], strained metal particles, for example in methanol synthesis on the industrial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst [90] and/or interfaces between different catalyst components, as has been hypothesized, for example, in CO oxidation on gold catalysts [28,91–93]. It needs to be noted that this is just a small list of examples. Active sites on heterogeneous catalysts and their detailed nanostructure are often a matter of lively debate among researchers. CO oxidation on gold might serve as an example, because the active site has been argued to be located at metallic gold sites (Au0) [94,95], at cationic gold sites [96,97], on gold particles near the interface [98], at the interface/perimeter between the gold nanoparticles and the oxide support [25,28,91–93], or on both neutral and cationic gold, depending on the temperature range under investigation [99] (for a more complete overview over the discussed active sites the reader is referred to ref. [99]). Reactions on single-site catalysts, such as epoxidation and selective oxidation reactions on the tetrahedral titanate (TiO4) species in TS-1 [100], might be an exception, because here all active sites have been delicately prepared to be of the exact same structure, very much like in homogeneous catalysis. In conclusion, the structure on the nanoscale decides whether a material is suitable as catalyst for a particular reaction or not, regardless of whether we can characterize this structure in detail or not. Catalysis and the design of nanostructures are thus inseparably linked to each other. 2.2 Methanol synthesis from synthesis gas and from CO2 A showcase molecule often discussed for chemical energy storage, in particular as future liquid fuel, is methanol. Both George Olah [101] and researchers from Aachen in Germany, such as Friedrich Asinger [102,103] very much advertised a “methanol economy”, in which this simplest alcohol can be used as a substitute to petroleum and/or as an alternative to hydrogen gas as fuel in a wide range of applications. It is also a versatile platform chemical, because chemical products such as formaldehyde and acetic acid can be produced from it, and it can be further converted to olefins and gasoline in respective processes (methanol-to-olefins, MTO and methanol-to-gasoline, MTG) [82]. Since methanol is of high toxicity and has a lower energy density compared to other hydrocarbons, and also due the fact that additional infrastructure would be needed for its distribution, this optimistic view of the methanol economy is not beyond doubt [38]. Regardless whether such a methanol economy will once become reality or remain a work of fiction, scientific progress is still needed before methanol can actually be considered a renewable resource. Today's industrial methanol synthesis is based on natural gas as source for the synthesis gas. The feed gas of the methanol synthesis plant thus consists of CO, CO2 and H2, allowing in principle three reactions to take place that interconvert reactants and products, namely methanol synthesis from CO (1), methanol synthesis from CO2 (2), and the water gas shift reaction (WGS, 3): (1) CO + 2 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 OH (2) C O 2 + 3 H 2 ⇌ C H 3 OH + H 2 O (3) CO + H 2 O ⇌ C O 2 + H 2 Although it has been shown that CO2 is the primary carbon source for methanol formation on the commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst [104–106], the system can only operate with high activity and display long term stability when an excess of CO is contained in the synthesis gas. On the one hand, this is due to the fact that a high CO partial pressure is favorable to increase the thermodynamically limiting equilibrium conversion to methanol [39,82]. This problem could be solved by process design, if a multi-pass reactor was used. On the other hand, since water formation as a byproduct is necessarily required by stoichiometry when methanol synthesis proceeds from the reactant CO2 (see Eq. 2), CO is needed to consume this water in the water gas shift reaction (Eq. 3). The interaction of water with the surface of the commercial catalyst is too favorable, so product inhibition occurs [82,107–109]. An alternative process needs to be developed, in which ideally methanol can be produced from only waste carbon dioxide together with hydrogen from water electrolysis or photocatalytic water splitting. Two challenges need to be tackled for this purpose: Firstly, high pressures are needed in the industrial methanol synthesis process today. While synthesis gas production from natural gas can easily be integrated in high pressure processes, the low pressures and low hydrogen concentrations of product gases from water electrolyzers and photocatalytic devices present significant obstacles. The activity of the catalyst would need to be significantly improved, so the process can be operated at extremely low temperature. Only then high pressures would no longer be required for a favorable thermodynamic equilibrium conversion. Secondly, considering the thermodynamic and water-inhibition limitations discussed above, one would need to convert a significant part of the CO2 to CO first. This could conveniently be done employing the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS, reverse reaction of Eq. 3) [110], but more regeneratively produced hydrogen would be consumed in this process, and the water produced in the RWGS would then need to be separated beforehand. Instead of making alterations to the process design only, some possible solutions can also be found in the nanostructure of the catalyst. The catalyst itself and its surface can be modified, to make it more active at low temperature, more tolerant to water, and to suppress the unwanted RWGS, which would both consume the valuable hydrogen and form the undesired byproduct water. It needs to be stated, however, that the nanostructure of the established Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst responsible for its high and stable catalytic activity has been under debate for decades [90,111–126], pointing out that it is likely extremely complex. It is thus a very challenging task to make further improvements to this system without at the same time disturbing the delicate balance and interplay of the state of the copper component (high surface area; charge, nature and location of exposed Cu sites; stacking faults, lattice strain) [111–118], the interaction and interface between Cu and ZnO [119–122], vacancies in ZnO and its reducibility [123,124], and/or a ZnO decoration on Cu particles [90,125,126]. A controlled synthesis strategy with an identification of relevant precursor phases might be the first step in the design of catalysts with tailor-made nanostructure and higher activity/stability in CO2 hydrogenation. For example, it has been shown that two Cu/ZnO-based catalysts, one produced from a zincian malachite precursor, the other from a hydrotalcite precursor, reacted very differently to the same reaction conditions: The malachite-derived catalyst could operate at 11% CO2 conversion, compared to 3.3% conversion observed with the hydrotalcite-derived catalyst, although 3.5 times as much water were produced in the former case [82]. With respect to the component ZnO, it has been shown for methanol synthesis on both the pure oxide [127] and on Cu/ZnO catalysts [128], that an exposure of preferably polar surfaces of ZnO increases the activity. Another possibility lies in alterations to the surface structure of the catalyst to make it more hydrophobic. In this regard, in a stoichiometric CO2:H2 feed gas (1:3) and at temperatures between 523 and 543K, an extremely high selectivity to methanol of more than 99% has been observed for Cu–Zn–Ga-catalysts when they were supported on hydrophobic silica [129]. In general, Ga2O3 and ZrO2 are the most common promoters for methanol synthesis from CO2(-rich) feed [82,107,108,129–135]. Often, the modifiers were thought to change the Cu dispersion [108,130–134] or the intrinsic activity of the active sites, as reflected in activation barriers and preexponential factors [108,130,134]. Additionally, one possible explanation is that the lower affinity of ZrO2 to water, as compared with the traditional alumina support, was responsible for the superior catalytic activity [107,134]. 2.3 Use of CO2 in Fischer–Tropsch synthesis A related approach is a recycling of carbon dioxide in a modified Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) as a means to store energy by the formation of long chain hydrocarbons. Even the traditional FTS is already well placed in discussions on energy conversion, since it provides a feasible way to convert coal or natural gas over a synthesis gas step (CO+H2) to liquid fuels [136,137]. This was the main incentive for the industrial application of the FTS in Germany during the Second World War [137]. In principle, any renewable source for syngas can be alternatively considered for the FT process, such as biomass [138]. The synthetic fuels from FTS are furthermore free of sulfur and aromatics [139]. The detailed mechanism of FTS is debated, because based on experimental observations both a carbide mechanism [139–141] and a CO insertion mechanism are likely [141–144]. In spite of this dispute, it is long known that irrespective of the used heterogeneous catalyst and the reaction conditions the main mechanism of FTS is a surface polymerization reaction of intermediates that were formed from CO on the catalyst surface [139,145]. This implies, necessarily, that always a multitude of products of different chain length will be obtained. The main products of FTS are linear alkanes and terminal olefins, but branched alkanes, alcohols, aldehydes, acids and ketones are also commonly found [136,139,145]. Thus, FTS would allow not only a conversion of renewable synthesis gas to fuels with the aim of energy conversion and storage, but it would also provide a means, for example, for a regenerative supply of olefins for the chemical industry. As generally unwanted byproducts the formation of methane and CO2 can occur, in particular on Ni- and Fe-based catalysts, respectively [136]. The selectivity of FTS can be directed to different products depending on the nature of the catalyst and the reaction conditions, but since those issues are outside the scope of this review, the reader is referred to other excellent publications [136,137,139,145]. The integration of CO2 into FT processes is somewhat more complicated than in the methanol synthesis process. For methanol formation on Cu catalysts, CO2 is already the preferred reactant from synthesis gas, and although product inhibition by water occurs, this problem can be handled by process and catalyst optimization (see above). In the Fischer–Tropsch process, though, CO is the main reactant, and it depends on the nature of the catalysts, whether it can handle CO2 in the feed at all and how the system reacts in terms of reaction rate and selectivity. The catalysts generally applied for FTS are cobalt- and iron-based systems. Ru- and Ni-based systems could in principle be used, too, but Ru is prohibitive due to its high price and scarcity, while on nickel methane formation is predominant [136]. The synthesis of current industrial cobalt catalysts has been optimized to yield Co particle sizes of 6–8nm. Larger particles are not more active, and smaller ones show lower activity [146], so this particle size allows the most efficient use of cobalt. Furthermore, expensive metal promotors such as Pt, Re or Ru are industrially used to enhance reducibility and help to maintain the large dispersion of the Co component [146]. As a third parameter, the activity, in particular for the formation of C5+ products, strongly depends on the catalyst support and the presence of alkali and alkaline earth metal and sulfur impurities [145,146]. Alumina in its γ-phase appears to be the predominantly used support, but silica, zirconia and titania are also used, including mixtures of the oxides [145–147]. For a more detailed overview over current industrial formulations for cobalt catalysts the reader is referred to the thorough overview in Ref. [146]. For iron catalysts, the active phase for FTS is considered to be a carbide phase, while iron oxides are assumed to be responsible for WGS activity [61,137,148]. The synthesis and composition of iron catalysts is different for those catalysts used for low-temperature operation and those for high-temperature operation. For low-temperature operation, catalysts are typically promoted with K and Cu, and silica is added as a binder, with a composition of approximately 5g K, 5g Cu and 25g SiO2 per 100g of iron [136,137]. For high-temperature operation, the structural promotors are alumina and MgO, and the complete catalyst is obtained by fusing the respective oxide together with magnetite and chemical promotors such as K2O [136]. A more complete description of industrial iron catalysts for the FTS can be found in Ref. [136]. The main issue related to the use of CO2 as reactant is the ability of the catalyst to also catalyze the water gas shift reaction. Cobalt-based catalysts show only low activity for the WGS [147], and while this is beneficial in the classical FTS from CO+H2 synthesis gas to suppress CO2 formation [149], it is detrimental for product yield when the aim is the use of CO2. In studies on different Co-based catalysts it was found that in the best of cases CO2 in the feed had only the effect of a diluting gas [150], leading to the requirement of larger reactor volumes to achieve the same production capacity from CO [151]. In one case additionally a deactivating effect was observed [151]. Another issue with Co-based catalysts is water management in the reactor: Even in CO2-free feed, water formation is necessarily required by stoichiometry when CO is used as reactant for hydrocarbon formation. As Co-based catalysts are not active for the WGS, the water accumulates with time-on-stream in multi-pass reactors [147]. While small amounts of water are beneficial for the activity of cobalt catalysts and the selectivity towards C5+ products and olefins [145,147], larger amounts might have strong negative effects, in particular at high Co dispersion [147,152]. This is the first issue related to nanostructure that has to be pointed out: The dispersion of Co is a crucial factor in FTS catalysts. Firstly, for practical reasons, the high price of cobalt necessitates to keep the Co content low for industrial application, which is generally best achieved by distributing the active metal in the form of small nanoparticles on suitable supports [136]. But secondly, from the view of catalysis, it has been found that the main factor influencing the activity is the available Co surface area [136,153], while the specific exposed crystal facets or the nature of the support was of minor importance [145,153]. The main effect of the support was an indirect one: The support needs to interact strongly enough with the Co nanoparticles to stabilize high dispersion, but not so strong that it would hinder complete reduction of CoO x to Co0 under reaction conditions, which is considered the active species in FTS [61,145,147,154]. In a related manner, reducing the size of the Co down to very small nanoparticles is detrimental for catalytic activity [145]. Furthermore, the detrimental effects of water have previously been attributed to a water-induced encapsulation of active Co metal by support species, or the formation of irreducible species, for example cobalt silicates [155] or cobalt aluminates [156] (for a more complete overview over the influence of water and deactivation mechanisms of Co-based catalysts the reader is referred to refs. [145,147].) Summing up the aforementioned discussion, the challenges in nanostructure engineering of Co-based catalysts for FTS from CO2, or at least a CO2-rich feed, are clearly defined: Firstly, the RWGS activity of the system has to be improved. Secondly, appropriate supports have to be employed or developed that stabilize small Co particles, even in the presence of high amounts of water, but without encapsulation of the Co particles, or a reaction to irreducible compounds. Promoting RWGS activity can be achieved by the addition of manganese oxide [149,157]. The same can also be achieved with a mechanical mixture with a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst [158], but this will not be discussed here, since it does not involve alterations to the nanostructure. With respect to the support, the use of weakly interacting carbon materials such as active carbon, carbon nanotubes and nanofibers has been suggested [147] to avoid strong metal-support interactions [159,160]. Additionally, carbon nanotube-alumina hybrid supports have been successfully tested [161,162]. Experimentally, a higher reducibility leading to a more prevalent presence of metallic Co on carbon supports has been observed [160,161,163,164], and the ideal Co particle size on those supports was reported to be 6–8nm [164]. At a weight loading of Co below 5wt% some carbon-supported catalysts were found to be entirely inactive, which was attributed to the amorphous nature of the metal [165]. A higher selectivity to the unwanted byproduct methane has also been observed both in the traditional synthesis gas [164], and in CO2 hydrogenation, up to the point that methane was the only product formed [165]. It has been suggested previously, though, that Co/Al2O3 and other oxide-supported Co catalysts turn to methanation catalysts in CO2/H2 feed, so this does not seem to be a direct consequence of the carbon support [150,157,166]. It has been suggested that the high hydrogenation activity of Co, in combination with lower carbon coverage in presence of CO2 instead of CO is responsible for methane formation [157] or that both reactions proceed on metallic cobalt via different pathways not sharing a common intermediate [167]. A possible solution to this problem might be a suitable pretreatment of the Co-based catalyst to convert it into different phases: When a Na-doped Co/SiO2 catalyst was pretreated in H2/CO feed, partially oxidized and carburized cobalt phases were formed that significantly suppressed methanation. Instead, the selectivity to alcohols was remarkably improved [168], which might also be useful products as future fuels or industrial raw materials. The addition of manganese, already known as a WGS promotor for FTS from CO2 [157], might alternatively be a way to suppress methane formation, as this dopant has been shown to increase the selectivity to longer chain hydrocarbons in classical FTS from CO+H2 feed [169,170]. This has been attributed to the suppression of the hydrogenation activity by decreasing Co reducibility and lowering the amount of adsorbed hydrogen [169]. In a related manner, doping of Co-based catalysts with earth-alkaline cations, transition metals and lanthanides [171], or an alloying with more reducible noble metals [61], can also be employed to selectively modify the reducibility of the cobalt component, both towards higher or lower reducibility. This might also be an option to adjust the state of cobalt to different feed gases. Iron-based catalysts already have an inherent activity in the WGS and RWGS [172], so at present they are more widely studied as catalysts for FTS from CO2 and considered advantageous [173]. In the classical process from CO and H2, an advantage of iron catalysts is also their stronger tendency to yield olefin products [135,174], which is relevant for industrial feedstocks. On Fe-based catalysts in the traditional CO+H2 feed, the necessary formation of water in FTS would always allow the WGS to occur, thus actually producing the unwanted byproduct CO2 [139]. For this type of catalysts, water clearly has an inhibiting role [175]. For Fe-based catalysts it has been argued that CO2 is not to a major extent directly hydrogenated to hydrocarbons [175], but mainly over an intermediate conversion to CO via the RWGS [135,138]. While in the case of Co-based catalysts the metallic phase is generally considered as active phase, in Fe-based catalysts in classical FTS the active phase is assumed to consist of a combination of iron carbides and iron oxides [61]. Since the active phase is anyway considered to be at least partially carbide, the use of carbon supports is a logical consequence. Carbon nanotubes are commonly grown from iron catalysts [176], so their use in iron catalysts does not cause problems with potential contamination. For iron catalysts supported on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) the catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation was twice as high compared to a related Fe/SiO2 catalyst. In this study, high amounts of C1 to C5 hydrocarbons with high percentage of olefins was obtained, and the improved activity was related to the better reducibility of the iron phase on the NCNTs compared to iron on OCNTs or on silica [148]. Although in another study iron species on non-doped carbon nanotubes were found to be reduced even more easily, the NCNTs as support led to the highest FTS activity of the resulting system in classical CO+H2 synthesis gas [177]. For Fe-based catalysts, manganese can also be a useful promoter, both structurally and electronically [135,178]. Both in classical FTS and in CO2 feed gas the methanation reaction was found to be suppressed [172,179]. Iron-manganese catalysts can be fabricated in the form of a mesoporous nanocomposite [180]. At high CO2 conversions, high yields of C2 to C5 hydrocarbons and little CO or methane formation were observed with this system, although the Mn content was low. The high activity was mainly attributed to the high surface area and high reducibility of the catalyst composite [180]. Other typical dopants for FTS by CO2 hydrogenation include potassium and copper [173,175,178,181,182]. While potassium is believed to increase WGS activity and adsorption of CO2 [173,182], Cu is thought to increase the reducibility of the catalyst [178]. Alternatively, in a Cu- and K-promoted iron catalyst, only a specific Fe5C2 phase was detected in the used catalyst, and it was suggested that this is the only active phase [181]. On a K- and Mn-codoped catalyst showing high activity for C2 to C5 olefin production, instead, a KAlH4 was found to contribute to the active phase. This phase is believed to reduce hydrogenation activity by acting as reversible hydrogen reservoir. In the same study, Mn was also thought to decrease hydrogenation activity by being deposited preferentially on the hydrogenation sites of iron [183]. Favorable results in CO2 hydrogenation have also been observed with K-promoted [184,185] and non-promoted Fe–Co bimetallic catalysts [186], in which methanation was strongly suppressed compared to Co catalysts and significant yields of the industrially relevant C2 to C4 olefins have been obtained. Here, the mechanism is also thought to involve the formation of CO or a closely related intermediate [184,185]. In conclusion, comparable to the consideration of the methanol synthesis catalyst shown above, the understanding and detailed structural characterization of working FTS catalysts in the classical CO+H2 feed can be used to suggest modifications to the catalyst to allow for CO2 hydrogenation. Care needs to be taken, though, that those modifications inadvertently will also alter other properties of the catalyst that have so far been favorable. Then the selectivity might shift to methane, or the product spectrum might be changed to a different range of products. It is clear, however, that first important steps towards efficient CO2 hydrogenation have already been taken that will certainly be built upon in the future. 2.4 Liquid fuels from biomass The approaches described above were all focused on the use of synthesis gas for the generation of future liquid fuels (methanol or hydrocarbons). It has already been mentioned that synthesis gas can also be obtained from biomass. However, gasification processes of biomass entirely destroy the complex chemical nature of the biomass components. It might be a superior process to retain some of the chemical structures already present in biomass for liquid fuel generation. This is done, for example, in the formation of biodiesel from edible oils and fats [187]. Three polymers from plant biomass might be preferably exploited which do not compete with food production, that is cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. Cellulose has already been explored as feedstock for a long time, but mainly over a hydrolysis route, proceeding over fermentable sugars to bioethanol. Acid catalysis and enzymatic breakdown of the cellulose can be applied for this purpose [188], but neither of the two processes has anything to do with a nanostructured inorganic material. In a related manner, the acid or base catalyzed esterification reaction of triglycerides with methanol for biodiesel production does not employ a nanostructured material, either [187]. In general, in this research field, the term “nanostructure” appears to be rarely used, in particular with respect to possible technologies for biomass conversion. If the term is used at all, it usually describes a certain nanostructure of a carbon material obtained from biomass, for example in a hydrothermal carbonization (HTC) process [189]. Some carbon materials will be discussed below in Section 3, but this topic is not the focus of this part of the review. There is one simple and predominant reason for the rare association of the terms “fuels from biomass” and “nanostructure”: Heterogeneous catalysts cannot simply be used for biomass conversion, of course, since in that case both the reactant and the catalyst would be present in the solid state. Heterogeneous catalysts can only enter the scene once the solid biomass has already been transferred into a liquid or gaseous state. In that sense, most technological advances in biomass conversion are in fact of chemical or process engineering nature [190–193]. A direct biomass fuel cell (BMFC) has also been reported, in which simple components of biomass, such as glucose, sucrose, ethanol and polysaccharides were fed to the fuel cell directly [194]. Another interesting approach is mechanocatalysis for the depolymerization of raw biomass, in which the action of an inorganic acid on the biopolymer is strongly amplified by mechanical forces, e.g. in a planetary ball mill [188]. Obviously, nanostructured materials are not relevant for such a process, either. If the complete disintegration of non-food biomass to synthesis gas is attempted to be avoided, there are two typical liquid intermediate states that can be used: In the first option, a well-defined molecule as platform chemical can be synthesized, such as 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) [195] or 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) [191,196,197]. Another option is the transformation of biomass into the so-called “fast pyrolysis oil”, or “bio-oil”, which in spite of its ill-defined nature might already be used or stored as liquid fuel. However, the rather significant content of organic acids in bio-oils makes it corrosive towards many construction materials. Another problem is non-miscibility with diesel fuel, so surfactants are needed for emulsification. To upgrade the bio-oils to conventional transport fuel, deoxygenation is required, but the processes applied, namely hydrotreating/hydrodeoxygenation and catalytic vapor cracking, are virtually similar to those in petroleum refining, including the used catalysts [187,190,192,198]. This is essentially also true for the chemically better defined hydrodeoxygenation of vegetable oils, although some improvements of Ni, Mo, NiMo, or CoMo catalysts were achieved by an optimization of the support material [187]. Similarly, pyrolysis and reforming of bio-oil with the aim to produce hydrogen can be carried out, but again the same processes as for naphtha are applicable [190]. An incorporation of renewable resources in established processes is always the simplest and preferred option, so the potential for new nanostructured materials in this field appears to be low. One might argue that new processes need to be developed anyway, since the integration of bio-oils in conventional fossil fuel processes is not yet economically feasible [190], and since today's commercial catalysts perform worse and show shorter lifetimes in bio-oil treatment [187]. Ref. [187] also sums up a complete list of properties that an ideal catalyst for bio-oil upgrading should exhibit, including, for example, a higher tolerance towards coking, water, and poisons. However, it appears questionable whether the intent to change the established processes completely will make the use of bio-oil economically feasible in the near future. The inability to specifically design a nanostructure for bio-oil processing is likely due to the complex chemical nature of this feedstock. Things change, however, if just one particular reactant and/or product is targeted. In this respect, fructose can be transformed into HMF in an acid-catalyzed process, and then converted further to DMF on a Cu–Ru catalyst [195]. The development of this particular Cu–Ru/C catalyst is a beautiful example of a nanostructuring strategy: While CuCrO4 catalysts were known to hydrogenate the aldehyde functionality in furfural, Ru/C catalysts can tolerate chlorine impurities in the reaction mixture, but would hydrogenate the furan ring. It was speculated that in a mixed Cu–Ru/C catalyst the Cu with its lower surface energy would cover the Ru, thereby creating a catalyst that behaved like copper in hydrogenation reactions, but was stable in presence of chlorine. In fact, 71% yield of DMF was experimentally confirmed [195]. In another study, for the synthesis of 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) an attempt with a nanostructured TiO2 catalyst has been reported. The porous TiO2 was synthesized using a biopolymer-templating approach. The high activity for HMF formation from mannose, lactose, and galactose was explained with the formation of strongly acidic sites on the nano-TiO2 [199]. Other nanostructures employed for HMF synthesis comprise rod-like copper hydrogen phosphate nanostructures [200] and sulfated hollow ZrO2 nanoshells as solid superacids [201]. For a more complete overview over processes for HMF synthesis, the reader is referred to the review in Ref. [202]. In the nanostructured systems reported above as examples, apart from the moderate to extremely high acid strength of the system, there seems to be no commonality. Since general concepts are supposed to be discussed in this review, we will thus not consider the topic further. Instead, we will close this paragraph with the conclusion that the design of nanostructures for the conversion of liquid bio-resources is an extremely challenging task due to the complexity of the reactant mixture. 2.5 Solar thermal approaches In brief, we will also consider thermochemical cycles based on concentrated solar energy for hydrogen or synthesis gas production. The main steps in those cycles comprise the reduction of a suitable metal oxide to the corresponding metal or a lower-valence oxide at very high temperatures and in absence of oxygen, followed by a partial cool-down and the introduction of water and/or CO2 that reoxidizes the metal oxide, thereby releasing hydrogen and/or CO [203]. For the splitting of water, the general reaction equations can be written as follows (Eqs. 4 and 5) [204]: (4) M O ox + thermal energy → M O red + 1 / 2 O 2 (5) M O red + H 2 O → M O ox + H 2 (For an overview over non-oxide systems, please see Ref. [204].) While the process can reduce the required energy compared to the spontaneous thermal dissociation of water and solves the problem of the separation of the two products H2 and O2 [204], it still requires very high temperatures. For many oxides, though, either the thermal reduction or the hydrolysis step is not feasible [205]. Three possible and most studied systems based on just one metal are the pairs ZnO/Zn [206–208], Fe3O4/FeO [208–210] and CeO2/Ce2O3 [205], in which the reduction steps require temperatures of ∼2000°C, 2200°C and 2000°C, respectively [205,206]. Looking at the numbers alone it becomes clear that an engineering of nanostructures can be omitted in this case, since likely no well-engineered nanomaterial with high surface area, high porosity or a delicately adjusted crystal structure will survive those temperatures and the very demanding structural stress in terms of reduction and reoxidation cycles. Sintering is thus a pressing problem [211]. An approach with evaporation of a zinc melt and the reaction of Zn nanoparticles in the gas phase with steam has been reported [212], but the resulting ZnO was not recycled in this study, so it was not an actual cycle. The more common approach is the use of high-temperature ceramics. The only issue with respect to “nanostructure” here is the development of a suitable material that allows removal of oxygen at reasonably low temperature and at the same time has sufficient thermal stability. Ferrite systems [213–215] and mixed cerium oxides [216] have been proposed and might be viable options. However, due to the marginal overlap with the topic “nanostructure”, the reader is referred to the corresponding articles and other thorough reviews on the topic of thermochemical cycles [203,204]. 3 Nanostructure in electrochemical energy conversion and storage The field of electrochemical energy conversion and storage is very broad therefore we will focus in this review on nanostructures of electrodes for water splitting as showcase for solar fuel generation, in this case hydrogen. 3.1 Nanostructured materials for electrocatalysts 3.1.1 Reactions in electrolyzers and fuel cells Energy conversion in the field of electrochemistry has to be considered in both directions: Both the storage of electrical energy by the production of hydrogen, a chemical energy carrier with a high energy capacity, and the counter reaction, the consumption of hydrogen in fuel cells in times of a demand of energy, are of great interest. Hydrogen can be produced by the electrocatalytic splitting of water. Efficient water splitting solely happens when the anode, where oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occurs, and the cathode, where hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) takes place, are functionally interacting. The reactions that occur in such electrolyzers are shown in Eqs. (6) and (7) for acidic media. (6) 4 H + + 4 e − ⇌ 2 H 2 ( HER , cathode ) (7) 2 H 2 O ⇌ O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − ( OER / ORR , anode / cathode ) Regaining the stored energy is realized by the controlled combustion of hydrogen and air in a fuel cell, where the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) takes place at the anode (Eq. 8) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) takes place at the cathode, which is the reverse OER reaction (Eq. 7). (8) H2⇌ 2 H+ +2 e− (HOR, anode) The two processes of electrical energy conversion are visualized in Fig. 2 . A more detailed analysis of the reaction mechanism reveals several elementary steps dependent on the electrolyte media as summarized in Table 1 . Regarding the thermodynamic potentials determined at standard procedures the most energy evolving pathway is the four electron route with the highest potential of 1.229V [218]. The complexity of dissociation and recombination steps of the formed gases and their intermediates are shown in Scheme 1 . The formation and sorption processes of the intermediates (OOHads, OHads, Oads) on the catalyst surface are the rate-determining factors. While the ORR is rather limited by the formation of OOHads and removal of OHads, the OER is limited by the strong adsorption of OOHads or weak adsorption of Oads [219,220]. The binding between the intermediates and the catalyst surfaces were related to theoretical overpotentials providing a universal relationship for OER of various oxide surfaces [221]. RuO2 and IrO2 show the highest OER activities as calculated and depicted in the volcano plot [221] (Fig. 3 ) and also known from several experimental reports [222,223]. Moreover, the nanostructured surfaces are influencing the electrocatalytic activities. The (100) oriented crystal structures were found to be more active than the (110) surfaces in alkaline media [224]. Platinum as the most prominent electrocatalyst shows as well surface sensitive activity for OER and ORR. Pt with well-defined crystallographic orientations has been studied while diverse trends could be observed in dependence of alkaline or acidic media [225,226]. These noble metal catalysts and electrode materials such as Fe, Ni, Co have been studied extensively. The interested reader is referred to profound review articles [80,227–229]. The general mechanism in ORR in alkaline media is summarized for metal-free and metal-containing compounds in detail pointing out future challenges [230]. In this review we will focus on manganese oxides as promising candidates (Fig. 4 ) for the replacement of non-abundant noble metals. Manganese plays a major role as an environmental friendly and abundant alternative in electrochemistry [231]. 3.1.2 Basic architecture of electrode materials Electrode materials have to fulfill several requirements, explicitly a fast mass transport to achieve high activities, which is related to the binding energies of intermediates as implied in the previous paragraph. Additionally fast charge transfer and long-term stability are essential for applicable electrodes. Electrode materials for OER and ORR have to resist the harsh conditions where oxygen species are formed. The degradation of these materials is often accompanied with short time stabilities and is therefore in the focus of interest [232,233]. To overcome these challenges the architecture of electrodes often consists of two parts. The basis is a conductive support, taking over the function of charge carrier transport while catalytic active particles are connected to it. The support material fulfills therefore additionally the role as anchoring and stabilizing material with a high surface area. Potential candidates for conductive supports are carbon based materials like carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers, graphene, highly ordered mesoporous carbons, carbon black, carbon paper, carbon nanowalls or glassy carbon [234–237]. Carbon itself and nitrogen-doped carbon compounds developed in the past are reasonable electrode materials as recently reviewed [238–240]. However, metal residues from synthesis processes where metal precursors are used may significantly influence the catalytic activities [241,242]. 3.1.3 Nanostructured manganese oxides as electrode materials Before discussing the combined electrode materials of conductive support and catalytic active manganese oxides we will report about manganese oxides by themselves in electrocatalysis. Molecular structures of manganese compounds are not reported in this review. The interested reader is referred to detailed review articles [243–246]. Due to the fact that manganese oxides and hydroxides exist in more than 30 types shows that it is a multifaceted dynamic compound [247,248]. The basic building blocks for nearly all manganese oxides are [MnO6] octahedra. The connectivity of these leads to three different types of nanostructures. There are dense 3D networks where the octahedra are connected via the edges. Less dense manganese oxides are formed by the arrangement of [MnO6]-chains, forming tunnels with different channel dimensions. The third group comprises layered manganese oxides with different interlayer distances and connectivities in the [MnO6] sheets (see Fig. 4). Channels and layers of the two later groups provide space for the intercalation of water or cations. Systematic studies of the different types are unfortunately rare and it is difficult to compare their properties as water oxidation catalyst (WOC) of different literature sources due to the lack of standardized test conditions for electrode materials. Frey et al. synthesized a whole portfolio of manganese oxides, compared the nanostructural motifs and tested them as WOC. The general WOC activity was determined to follow the trend of 3D structures < tunneled structures ≈ layered oxides [249]. This correlates with earlier work where the structural motifs were related to electrocatalytic activities [250–252]. The influence of the nanostructured manganese oxide crystals will be further elucidated by the comparison of different tunnel structured MnO2 components. The channels that are formed by the interlinked [MnO6] octahedra via the edges or corners possess (1×1) tunnel in case of β-MnO2, (1×1) and (1×2) in case of γ-MnO2 and the largest tunnels of (2×2) and (1×1) are formed in α-MnO2 (Fig. 4). The catalytic activity can be correlated by the systematic study to follow the trend of α- > β- > λ- > γ-MnO2 according to the presence of suitable tunnel nanostructures, the abundance of OOHabs and large surface areas [253,254]. The impact of the nanostructures on the ORR mechanism was investigated by comparative studies of defect-rich manganese oxide compounds. The presence of vacancies in the oxygen lattice enables a more positive potential and therefore a better formation of OOHads, which is the rate determining step in ORR as mentioned before in Section 3.1.1 [255]. Accordingly ε-MnO2, a defect-rich [256] component shows a higher electrochemical activity than α-MnO2 [257]. Correspondingly a comparative study of three different MnO2 morphologies showed that the highest ORR activities do not correlate with the highest surface area, but rather with the highest ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ which is conterminously with a higher oxygen vacancy density [258]. Defects in the structure are also generated by a post-treatment of the synthesized materials. Calcination is hereby the most applied technique [259,260]. Theoretical investigations are in accordance with experimental data and show an enhanced catalytic activity with an increase of oxygen vacancy concentrations in the β-MnO2 structure. However, an excessive amount of defects in the lattice degrades the ORR performance [261]. Regarding the Pourbaix-diagram of manganese (Fig. 5 ), we see that we are not dealing with a static system. It is rather dynamic and changeable especially when we consider that the reactions take place in aqueous media and solid-electrolyte interfaces are present. The thermodynamically most stable phases are a function of pH and potential [262]. Investigations in acidic, neutral and alkaline media were performed and exhibit two reaction mechanisms. Under alkaline conditions a self-healing procedure due to redeposition of MnOx was suggested [263]. Combined theoretical and experimental research of different manganese oxides additionally verifies the influence of the bulk structure and the near-surface structure that is strongly depending on pH [264]. Furthermore it was shown that α-MnO2 is an excellent bi-functional catalyst for ORR and OER due to phase changes on the surface [264,265]. Not directly visible from the Pourbaix-diagram are the influence of temperature and the ions of the electrolyte [266–268]. It was reported that the intercalation of cations in the nanostructure during the electrolysis in dependence of the electrolyte enhances the effect of electrocatalytic activity. Synthesis of layered manganese oxides with different cations was consequently performed, showing an increase in catalytic performance [269–272]. Systematic studies of earth alkaline cations showed a trend in the order of Ca2+> Sr2+> Mg2+. Until now no reasonable explanation for the trends of intercalated cations could be determined. Interestingly, it follows the trend observed in biological PSII and their substituted Sr2+ and Mg2+ forms [273]. The influence of the macroscopic nanostructures have to be considered as well, having in mind that reactants and products of the electrocatalytic reactions have to be transported back and forth in the electrolyte media to the active sites of the electrodes. The attachment of formed gas bubbles is a serious problem, especially when the concentration of produced gases overcomes the saturation in the electrolyte and stick to the surface or more precisely to the active sites of the catalyst [274,275]. Nanostructures of the catalyst surface that prevent the formation of big gas bubbles and promote the detachment of those are favorable. Cracks, pores, channels or combinations of these can avoid the nucleation of gas bubbles [276–279]. The morphology of manganese oxides is manifold, bulk particles, nanowires, flowerlike nanospheres or needles are only an extract of the variety of structures (Fig. 6 ) [254,280]. The synthesis of different nanostructures is very broad and reaches from very simple one-pot synthesis to slightly more advanced hydrothermal synthesis in autoclaves and via electro deposition techniques to gas-phase reactions by atomic layer deposition (ALD) [265,281–288]. The optimization of both, the synthesis and material properties is required to fully exploit the potential of manganese oxides [289]. To decouple the relationship between textural properties and oxidation states, controlled synthesis of nonporous nanocrystalline metal oxides with tunable manganese oxidation states was realized for systematic investigations [290]. It turned out that Mn3+ is essential for the oxygen evolution [290–293]. Disproportionation of Mn3+ to Mn2+ and Mn4+ occurs at pH <9 accompanied with higher overpotential whereas comproportionation takes place in alkaline media [292]. The implementation of electrocatalysis is therefore strongly dependent on the electrolyte media and has to be chosen cautiously. On the other hand different nanostructures of manganese compounds with well-defined oxidation states were synthesized to study the influence of the nanostructures [253]. The comparative work of different morphologies of α-MnO2 shows that nanostructured nanowires and nanospheres perform much better than microsized bulk particles as depicted in Fig. 6 [254]. Furthermore, there are also reports where the preparation technique has a significant influence on the catalytic behavior due to slightly different nanostructures. Hence, the influence on the shift of the overpotential is more or less pronounced, dependent on the electrolytes [294]. 3.1.4 Hierarchical manganese oxides as electrode materials Hierarchical structures of manganese oxides have received a lot of attention due to the beneficial interplay of macroscopic and nanoscopic properties. High surface areas provide high accessibilities for mass transport coupled with strong interaction of the catalytic active and the conductive layers for favorable electron transfer [295,296]. Multi-walled structures of MnO2 and conductive polypyrrole walls were synthesized by sequences of hydrothermal processes or anodic–cathodic pulse-plating (Fig. 7 ). The layer-by-layer techniques overcome the challenges of low conductivities of the manganese oxides and provide high surface areas. Additionally Mn3+ is the dominant species in the electrodeposited samples. Hence, this results in comparable ORR activities to Pt/C with even better long-term stabilities [297,298]. An efficient Mn3O4/CoSe2 nanocomposite was synthesized by heterogeneous nucleation of Mn3O4 nanoparticles on the CoSe2 surface exploiting the synergetic coupling effects. Due to the homogeneous distribution of nucleation sites, nanoparticles with higher surface area instead of nanorods are stabilized. The enhanced OER activity is additionally explained by a shift of the binding energy of Co 2p of about 0.84eV correlated with an electron transfer from Mn3O4 to CoSe2 [299,300]. Three-dimensional hierarchical structures of Mn3O4 nanoflakes were electrodeposited on nitrogenated reduced graphene oxide. The laterally protruding flakes provide high surface areas and therefore good mass transport abilities. The conductivity between the electrodeposited manganese oxide and the support enables efficient electron transport, so that high OER activities were reported [301]. To overcome the limitations of mass and electron pathways hierarchical structures of nitrogen-doped reduced graphene were connected together by cross-linking agents and subsequent pyrolysis to achieve sufficient conductivity between the separated graphene flakes. Manganese was added to the system by impregnation method. The comparative electrochemical testing reveals the beneficial effect of interlinking and manganese deposition. Enhanced OER activities as well as ample long-term stability could be shown [302]. 3.1.5 Manganese oxides supported on structured carbon materials as electrode materials Manganese oxides are poor conductors. To overcome the limitations of the low electronic transfer they are often deposited on, or combined with conductive support materials, which have a tremendous influence on the catalytic activities. This is not only due to the charge transfer that can be diverted over the support, but also because of higher surface areas and the limited growth of gas bubbles that lead to better detachment and therefore higher catalytic activities as mentioned before. The support material can stabilize preferential orientations as well as oxidation states or particle shapes and sizes of the deposited catalytic particles. Especially carbon structures that are synthesized by template techniques possess high surface areas that are required in the field of energy storage [303]. Here we will report about the effects of different carbon support materials that are often used in electrocatalysis. Carbon materials containing graphene-like structures are attractive forms for electrode materials. Their contribution to the catalytic performance can tremendously depend on the orientation and access to edge planes sites or tube ends, which have been reported as active sites (Fig. 8 ) [304]. Nanostructured carbon materials that play important roles in the field of energy storage are summarized in related review articles [73,303,305]. Simple mixing of manganese oxides with carbon powder is often applied [257,306]. The influence of different carbon powder suppliers was studied, demonstrating the impact of morphology and composition of the synthesized compounds [307]. It can lead to much higher limiting current densities than their neat base material as shown in Fig. 6 [254]. In another case where cobalt manganese spinel nanoparticles were mixed with carbon powder the material shows comparable activities to the benchmarking platinum carbon (Pt/C) compounds in ORR and even better performance in OER [308]. This could be further confirmed by mixing of MnCo2O4 with graphene oxide or nitrogen-doped graphene oxide as conductive support [309,310]. Enhanced ORR activities were also shown by the comparative studies with mixtures of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) and graphene oxide [311]. The ideal combination of high surface aspect ratio, mechanical strength, electric conductivity and the ability of chemical/physical modifications makes carbon nanotubes to one of the most explored nanostructured materials [312]. In comparison to related sp 2 carbon structures the outer walls of MWCNT can be modified while maintaining high conductivity due to undamaged inner walls [313,314]. The drawback of simple mixing technique is the limited interaction of active particles and structured carbon, hence not all active sites are coupled to the support material. Deposition of manganese oxides on MWCNT was applied by symproportionation or impregnation technique and compared to pure manganese oxide (Fig. 9 ). The evolution of the Mn oxidation states in dependence of calcination temperature was determined with L-NEXAFS. It was shown that the MWCNT are able to stabilize the favored oxidation state of Mn3+ which also results in higher catalytic performance [315]. Hereby the pre-functionalization of the MWCNT before the deposition of manganese oxides affects the properties of the catalytic activity [316]. Manganese oxides are further deposited on glassy carbon, a known electrode material with intrinsic high ORR activity, which can be additionally enhanced by generating defects on the surface [317,318]. Atomic layer deposition is hereby a promising technique to synthesize nanoengineered materials with covalent bonding of the deposited layer [286]. For electrochemical testing it is advantageous that the materials themselves can be measured without adding a binder like Nafion for instance which is needed for powder samples. The direct influence of the nanostructured surface of the support material was studied by ALD of manganese oxides on smooth and high surface area glassy carbon in comparison. Thin films on the nanostructured support material perform much better than their dense analogue films deposited on smooth surfaces. It turned out that thinner films are not limited in charge and mass transport and therefore show higher OER activity [319]. Comparing manganese oxides deposited on modified glassy carbon or gold surfaces reveal the huge impact of support material. Different processes happen during the O2 reduction due to the structural properties of the support material that stabilizes different MnO x phases [320]. Concluding with this section it can be summarized that structured carbon materials that support and stabilize homogeneously distributed Mn3+ nanoparticles are enhancing the electrocatalytic properties. A detailed systematic understanding of the support-particle interaction is required for further development. 4 Nanostructure in solar energy conversion 4.1 Introduction: photovoltaics and photocatalysis It would be the most desirable way of energy conversion and storage to convert sunlight directly into storable chemicals with high energy density. This is, after all, the approach that nature has been using for millions of years in natural photosynthesis. Unfortunately, the slow and rather inefficient natural photosynthesis for the production of biomass cannot keep up with the immense resource consumption of humankind today. There have thus been many attempts to reproduce the general principle of photosynthesis, that is, the generation of chemicals from solar light, water and CO2, but we have not yet been able to (bio)chemically fabricate an efficient artificial system [29,30]. While such approaches could in principle be realized either in the form of pure photocatalysis, or as photoelectrochemical cells [321], an industrial application of either of them for energy conversion and storage is currently nowhere in sight. On the other hand, the conversion of sunlight into electricity using photovoltaics is a well-established process. Si-based solar cells are already in development for more than 50 years, and already before the turn of the millennium, cells with an efficiency of almost 25% had been demonstrated [41,322]. Considering that the theoretical maximum efficiency has been reported to be around 31% (the so-called Shockley–Queisser limit) [41,323], this is fairly impressive. It indicates that it is likely not the absorption and general use of solar energy which hampers photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical applications, but, rather, the additional complications one is facing when the charge carriers generated by photoexcitation are not used as such, but are supposed to participate in particular chemical reactions. Then, not only the size of the band gap, but also the band edge positions are of crucial importance [321]. Furthermore, the generated charge carriers need to be transferred over a solid-fluid interface, and the surface needs to exhibit appropriate catalytic active sites to be able to catalyze the desired reaction. In this part of the review we will discuss general principles for the design of nanostructured materials for solar energy conversion, and we will highlight similarities and differences in the development of materials for photovoltaics and photocatalysts. Again, we will only focus on inorganic materials or hybrids of inorganic materials. For natural and artificial photosynthetic systems, organic-inorganic hybrid photocatalysts and dye-sensitized solar cells, the reader is referred to other thorough reviews on those topics [29,30,10,324,325]. We will also not consider perovskite solar cells, since it has been shown very impressively that nanostructuring is not necessary for these types of solar cells [326]. Lastly, we will not particularly focus on the catalytic functionalities, since those concepts have been discussed in detail above. A physical concept that inevitably needs to be considered with respect to nanosized semiconductors is the quantum size effect. In extended semiconductors, the formation of the band structure is based on the overlap of an almost infinite number of electronic states from atomic orbitals. Quantization of the energy thus cannot be noticed anymore, and the energy states appear to be distributed over a continuous band [327]. However, when the structural units of a semiconductor are reduced to smaller and smaller sizes, less and less electronic states overlap. In the range of moderate size confinement, this leads to a narrowing of the bands accompanied with an increase of the band gap. Going down in size to small agglomerates or polymers of the semiconductor, the band structure transforms into more and more discreet energy levels. In the extreme case of one isolated photoactive species, the photoexcitation takes place in discreet molecular orbitals, with the electron usually being excited from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) [328,329]. In Fig. 10 this concept is shown for a semiconductor such as TiO2 and the isolated titanate species. Since the unoccupied states of the (transition metal) cation usually contribute the LUMO, while in case of oxide species the O 2p orbital is the HOMO, this transition can be considered as a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) [328,330]. The LMCT through photoexcitation leads to the formation of a Ti3+ cation, while the oxidation state of one of the surrounding oxygen atoms is decreased from O2 − to O− [328]. These radicals can be characterized by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) [331]. The excitation of an electron in the isolated photoactive species from HOMO and LUMO necessarily requires much more energy than the excitation of an electron across the band gap of an extended semiconductor from the same material. In particular in the case of TiO2 and the isolated titanate, this can be considered highly unfavorable, because TiO2 already absorbs only UV light. Another important difference of extended semiconductors and isolated cations is the localization, the transport mechanism, and the lifetime of excited charge carriers. While in the extended semiconductor the photogenerated charge carriers can migrate more or less freely through the solid, the charge carriers are localized at their point of origin in case of the isolated site on a non-conducting support [332]. It might be inferred that the lifetime of charge carriers generated in isolated photoactive species is thus much shorter than in extended semiconductors. It has been shown, however, that this is not necessarily the case, i.e. that not necessarily an inverse correlation between charge carrier mobility and lifetime exists. For isolated titanate and vanadate species, for example, the lifetime of the excited state was reported to be much longer than in the corresponding extended oxides TiO2 and V2O5 [333,334]. Transport mechanisms within and to the outside of the material are of high importance. In this respect, it needs to be realized that only those charge carriers are available for energy conversion that can be extracted from the material [335]. In nanosized materials transport mechanisms are fundamentally different, because they crucially depend on the number and nature of defects in the material. Nanosized and structured materials usually bring along a large amount of disorder due to the breaking of the symmetry of the extended bulk solid.
