At grain boundaries or interfaces, dangling bonds and interactions with surrounding chemical species occur. Such defects are localized states for electrons and holes that can be considered as traps. In nanostructured materials, the traps might be the limiting factor for electron transport, because the migration of the electrons in those materials, often referred to as “hopping”, proceeds by thermal excitation and tunneling from trap state to trap state (Fig. 11 ) [335]. Summing up the aforementioned discussion, nanosized domains of photoactive materials might offer advantages and disadvantages. Just as for any other material, the reduction in size leads to a higher surface-to-volume ratio [329,335,336], so the diffusion path of the charge carriers to the surface, that is, to the point where they are supposed to react, is shorter. At the same time, the larger surface area might provide more adsorption sites for reactants, active sites for the catalytic process, and localized electronic states beneficial for the electronic transport and trapping near the surface [335,336]. All of those aspects are expected to be beneficial for the overall photocatalytic process. On the other hand, if the particle sizes become so small that size quantization occurs, the excitation energy increases, so an (even) smaller part of the light from the solar spectrum can be absorbed. The smaller size also induces a larger amount of disorder and defects, and while those favorably control electron transport [335], they might also act as recombination centers, which is detrimental for the photoefficiency [337]. 4.2 Photovoltaics In spite of some uncertainties with respect to benefits and drawbacks of nanosized photoactive materials outlined above, applications of nanomaterials in solar energy conversion are very common. Considering in a first instance photovoltaics, working devices could not be fabricated at all without manipulating the nanostructure of materials: Since most charge carriers are produced near the upper surface of the absorbing base layer, even for weakly absorbing materials like silicon, the emitter layer on top of it necessarily needs to be very thin to locate the separating p-n-junction close to the surface. The anti-reflection layer needs to be thin as well, because it should not majorly absorb radiation itself, but only function to reduce reflection. The general design of a solar cell is shown in Fig. 12 . For further explanation the reader is referred to Ref. [338] and the references therein. Far beyond the minimum requirements briefly outlined above, nanostructure engineering has been applied to construct systems such as, for example, thin-film and multi-junction solar cells, systems with one-dimensional nanostructures such as nanowires and nanotubes, and quantum-dot solar cells. While for a complete discussion of the solar cell concepts the reader is referred to Refs. [41,338], we will highlight some general concepts of nanostructure-based solar cells below, together with a discussion of why and how nanostructured materials can be applied in those systems. With respect to thin film solar cells, it first needs to be realized that crystalline silicon is physically not the ideal material for photovoltaics, because its indirect bandgap requires the use of rather thick films to allow for sufficient light absorption. It is mostly used due to considerations of availability and (relative) ease of manufacturing. A material with a direct band gap would be more suitable and could be used as much thinner films [338]. A replacement of Si with the material GaAs with direct band gap would allow a reduction in thickness from more than 100µm to about 1µm, that is, by about a factor of 100 [41]. Thus, the development of appropriate materials with direct band gap and efficient light absorption, such as the material Cu(In,Ga)Se2, often referred to as CIGS, or CdTe, is of utmost importance here. Using CIGS as absorber for thin film solar cells, efficiencies of close to 20% could be reached already in 1999 [339]. The use of thin films also reduces the necessity of long carrier diffusion length, or charge carrier lifetime. The need for long diffusion length is one of the main reasons for the need to use extremely high purity silicon in conventional solar cells [340]. If crystalline silicon is supposed to be used for thin film solar cells, although it is not the ideal material, then it is of tremendous importance to increase the grain size, i.e. reduce the amount of grain boundaries, because in Si the latter are efficient recombination centers. Furthermore, since crystalline Si is a weak absorber material, light trapping strategies have to be applied to achieve high degrees of internal reflection. This can be done by appropriately textured front surfaces and/or back contacts [338]. The negative influence of grain boundaries as observed in Si is not a universal observation, though: In the case of CdTe grain boundaries were suggested to enhance minority carrier collection [338]. Although both CIGS (and related materials) and CdTe have successfully been used, attempts are made to develop materials that do not contain scarce (In, Te) and/or toxic elements (Cd). As one alternative, the use of the material Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 from the kesterite family with efficiencies up to almost 10% has been demonstrated. For this class of materials, the control of the phase purity and the composition is the dominant challenge [340]. Using appropriate absorber materials, the construction of multi-junction or tandem solar cells can significantly enhance the theoretical maximum efficiency, for example to 71% for a four-junction cell. In this concept, from top to bottom materials with smaller and smaller band gap are stacked on top of each other, so that the whole solar spectrum is efficiently absorbed [41,338]. An additional challenge associated with tandem cells connected in series is that all cells in the stack need to absorb the same amount of photons [338]. To favorably influence both absorption and reflection, one-dimensional nanostructures such as nanowires, -rods, -tubes or -cones can also be applied, which can be traced back to light scattering between the nanostructures that increases the path length which the light has to travel in the structure [341,342]. It is important to note, though, that suppression of recombination is critical in inorganic nanostructures in solar cells, since there is usually a large amount of electronic defects present [342]. An example for a solar cell with extremely thin absorber layers has been fabricated on the basis of ZnO nanowires with a length of 1.5µm coated with the absorber material of only 25nm of In2S3 and CuSCN [343]. Plasmonic structures, that is, metallic nanostructures in which surface plasmons are exploited to concentrate light into thin semiconductor layers, have also widely been studied in recent times. Multiple physical processes in those materials allow reducing the actual (physical) thickness of an absorber material, while at the same time keeping its optical thickness constant. For details on this issue the reader is referred to Ref. [21]. In this respect, improved scattering and reradiation of light can also be achieved with periodically arranged photonic plasmonic structures fabricated by nano-imprint lithography [344]. Quantum-dot (QD) solar cells make use of the confinement of the exciton wave function in low-dimensional nanocrystals. As explained above, the necessary excitation energy increases due to quantum confinement. This allows a tuning of the excitation energy by means of size adjustment [342]. It is then possible to tune the QDs so that they absorb light with a too high energy for the absorber layer in the solar cell, and to the use of QDs for down-conversion of those high-energy photons, that is, to convert them to photons of lower energy that are of use to the absorber in the solar cell [41]. Up-conversion, the conversion of two photons of lower energy to one of higher energy, realized by absorption in intermediate bands might also be achieved by arrangements of QDs: If QDs are closely spaced, their electronic levels might overlap to form an effective band structure, which might be finely tuned to yield an intermediate band. Excitation into this band and from this band effectively allows the absorption of photons of too low energy [41]. The relatively easy synthesis of QDs is another favorable aspect [41,342]. It has been proposed that the use of quantum dots in solar cells might allow to go beyond the Shockley–Queisser limit and to achieve quantum efficiencies larger than one, but much fundamental research might still be needed to be able to fully exploit the specific physical effects such as, for example, hot charge carrier collection or multi-exciton generation in QDs [342]. 4.3 Expanding the concepts to photocatalysis In Ref. [338], Goetzberger et al. name as requirements of ideal solar cell materials that they (1) have a band gap between 1.1 and 1.7eV, (2) have a direct band gap, (3) are composed of abundant and non-toxic materials, (4) are suitable for large scale production, (5) are efficient in photovoltaic conversion, and (6) are stable for a long term. Comparing those requirements to materials for photocatalysis, the points (3) to (6) can be applied almost unchanged, with the slight alteration to replace “photovoltaic” with “photocatalytic” in aspect 5. In that sense, it has been recognized that many materials applied in photocatalysis are also used in photovoltaics [345]. With respect to requirement 1 and 2, however, requirements for photocatalysts for energy conversion reactions differ: For the water splitting reaction, which would require a minimum energy of 1.23eV if no overpotentials were present, a realistic ideal band gap for a single photoabsorber system of roughly 2eV has been predicted, considering overpotentials and other losses [346,347]. Furthermore, in photocatalysis materials with an indirect band gap appear to perform better than those with a direct band gap. This is associated with the reduced charge carrier recombination rates and thus extended lifetimes [348–351]. The possibly best known examples are anatase and rutile, the two crystal modifications of TiO2. While the band gap of rutile is a direct one, anatase features an indirect band gap [336]. The latter crystal structure has often been found more active in photocatalytic reactions compared to direct band gap rutile [348,351]. Another example is the material NaTaO3 with promising activity for overall water splitting. The control of the crystal structure by means of well-defined synthesis protocol allows selecting between a direct and an indirect band gap: While the orthorhombic phase has a direct band gap, the monoclinic phase has an indirect band gap and improved photocatalytic properties [349]. An additional requirement not necessary for solar cells is the presence of suitable catalytically active sites on the surface. Those sites can either be present on the native semiconductor, or they can be introduced purposefully by adding another element or compounds, often referred to as “cocatalyst”. The issue of active sites will not be discussed in detail again, because most aspects have been discussed above with respect to thermal catalysis. However, in photocatalysis in addition the energy levels of the catalytic functionalities need to be appropriately positioned. If a cocatalyst is supposed to act as reduction site, it is of no use if it acts as a hole trapping site. In another manner, it does not help if it traps and transfers electrons but does not bind the reactant that is supposed to be reduced. This implies that the necessary requirements for photocatalysts are more complex, because both the design principles for catalysts and for photoabsorbers need to be obeyed. Or, as explained by Kudo and Miseki [345] one needs the correct elements for the design of the crystal structure, the energy structure, potential impurity levels, and the catalytic functionalities. In this respect, the transition metal cations for the crystal/energy structure (i.e. the photoabsorber) are usually of d 0 or d 10 configuration [345] in their highest oxidation states [12]. If this condition is fulfilled, then the conduction band mainly consists of empty d orbitals of the constituent d 0 transition metal cation or of hybridized orbitals of empty s and p orbitals of d 10 cations, respectively [12]. Cocatalysts for the reduction reaction are usually (noble) metals, because they act as a reservoir for the photogenerated electrons [10]. The careful reader should have noticed that the discussion of photocatalytic materials so far did not quite fit into the section about solar energy conversion, because in fact most of the efficient materials for photocatalysis absorb only UV light, which is contained in solar irradiation only to some percent. One application of nanostructure engineering the field of photocatalysis is thus the doping of semiconductors with cations and/or anions, best exemplified again with TiO2. The aim here is to modify the band structure and thereby narrow the band gap, either by introduction of additional electronic states above the valence band or below the conduction band [332,336]. With respect to anion-doping, elements can be introduced with lower electronegativity compared to oxygen, with the aim that some of the anion's valence p-states are situated above the valence band maximum of TiO2. It is not clear whether those states would be localized or not [336]. As a third option aside from an increase in the valence band or a decrease in the conduction band, localized mid-gap states might also appear, as has been discussed, for example, for the case of nitrogen [332] or chromium [352] doping of TiO2. When bulk-doping strategies of TiO2 are supposed to be implemented, one needs to find the optimal balance between a sufficient amount of dopants to improve charge carrier trapping favorably, and an excess amount that would lead to more pronounced charge carrier recombination [336]. It might be an alternative way to restrict the doping of TiO2 to the surface of the material. For the case of tin doping in rutile TiO2 in the form of solid solutions, for example, the improved photocatalytic activity had anyway been partially ascribed to the segregation of Sn2+ ions to the surface of the material. When the divalent Sn2+ cation occupies a surface cation site, that is, a site that lacks inversion symmetry, orbital hybridization can take place that gives rise to a directional electron lone pair. This process provides a thermodynamic driving force for Sn2+ surface segregation [353,354]. Tests of a doping of anatase TiO2 with Sn2+ [355] and Sn4+ [356] restricted to the surface were successful to enhance photocatalytic activity in dye degradation and H2 evolution, respectively, which has been attributed to the action of Sn2+ as surface hole trap, while Sn4+ acted as surface electron trap [355,356]. Furthermore, it becomes more and more recognized that a tuning of defect structure and (non-)stoichiometry of complex oxides can also be used for an optimization of the photocatalytic activity. An example is the work on the pyrochlore-structured oxide Y2Ti2O7 by the group of M. Wark et al. [357]. Using advanced sol–gel-based synthesis methods, the introduction of a small excess of titanium cations in Y2Ti2O7 allowed minimizing the lattice distortion at lower calcination temperature, consequently resulting in a better ordered material with smaller particle sizes and larger surface area. This material (with Pt or Rh cocatalyst) was superior in hydrogen evolution from methanol/water mixtures compared to yttrium titanates without optimized nanostructure [357]. In conclusion, there is still much room for the further exploitation of nanostructures in the field of solar energy conversion. It is also strongly advised to establish more interdisciplinary cooperation between researchers working on photovoltaics with those working on photocatalysis, because the use of tailor-made nanostructures appears to be much further developed in photovoltaics. Furthermore, in particular in the field of photocatalysis, we should pay much more attention to the nanostructure of the material, just as is done in classical heterogeneous catalysis. It is expected that a detailed understanding of all components of the photocatalyst on the nanoscale, although probably difficult to achieve, would likely enable breakthroughs in the overall performance. Those are dearly needed to make photocatalysis attractive in the field of energy conversion from an industrial viewpoint. 5 Conclusions In the present review, current concepts for the use of nanostructured materials in the field of energy conversion and storage have been highlighted and compared. It became clear that in many sectors of energy conversion and storage, nanostructured materials are already used in a variety of different ways, for example in (thermal) heterogeneous catalysis and in photovoltaics. In catalysis, the nanostructure of the material, in particular of its surface, will always play a decisive role for its catalytic function, so that catalysis can never be discussed without at the same time discussing nanostructure, too. The construction of efficient photovoltaics is also only possible applying nanosized and nanostructured materials. We should use this knowledge that we have already obtained in those fields and built upon it, for example for the development of more active photocatalysts, and the design of active and stable materials for electrocatalysis. Already today we can see the improvements that are achievable, for example in the well-defined structuring of manganese oxides for water oxidation, the synthesis of carbon-based materials for electrodes, or the targeted development of cocatalysts and surface-dopants for photocatalysts. Furthermore, long established processes such as the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis can be optimized for new conditions and new feedstocks. For all of those developments, an understanding of the materials on their most elementary scale is a prerequisite. So the final advice in this review is to use all modern techniques for detailed structural and electronic characterization available today to broaden the basis of knowledge with respect to structure-function relationships, because this knowledge will allow an even better adjustment of nanostructure to the challenges in energy conversion in the future. coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured and nanosized materials are widely applied to tackle the pressing challenges associated with energy conversion. In this conceptual review, rather than highlighting separate examples, we aim to give a general overview about where and how nanostructure design can be beneficial in the three major research fields (photo)thermal chemical energy conversion, electrochemical energy conversion, and solar energy conversion. It will be shown that in many cases the design of catalytically active nanostructures is the main task and that especially for catalysts nanostructure and activity are inseparably linked to each other. Moreover, electrochemical and photochemical processes are complicated by the overlap of multiple processes that all need to be optimized, including in particular light absorption, charge migration, recombination and trapping events and surface processes. It will also be shown how the development of materials for new challenges can often be based on our knowledge on existing materials for related applications.

coredata.dc:title: Nanostructure in energy conversion
